facts.text: Writ Petition No. 278 of 1974 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 278 of 1974. Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India. K. Sinha and S. K. Sinha, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner is an advocate practising in the courts in Dhanbad in the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, who is an advocate practising in the companyrts in Dhanbad in the State of Bihar, has filed the present petition challenging the validity of an order

facts.text: Order of detention dated 18th March, 1974 made by the District Magistrate, Dhanbad under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: has filed the present petition challenging the validity of an order of detention dated 18th March, 1974 made by the District Magistrate, Dhanbad under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner has been Pramukh of Baliapur Anchal since the last about ten years.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner is that he is a prominent public figure in the District of Dhanbad and he has been Pramukh of Baliapur Anchal since the last about ten years

facts.text: Petitioner has been Vice-Chairman of Zila Parishad, Dhanbad since about four years.

anchor.surface_text: and Vice-Chairman of Zila Parishad, Dhanbad since about four years. He has been associated with numerous social, educational and political institutions

facts.text: 16th Annual Convention of Bihar Rajya Panchayat Parishad scheduled at Gosaidih in Dhanbad District on 16th March, 1974; petitioner was Chairman of Reception Committee.

anchor.surface_text: The 16th Annual Convention of Bihar Rajya Panchayat Parishad was scheduled to be held at Gosaidih in Dhanbad District on 16th March, 1974 and the petitioner was the Chairman of the Reception Committee.

facts.text: False case instituted against petitioner at P. S. Tundi.

anchor.surface_text: the ruling party chose this particular time when the 16th Annual Convention of the Bihar Rajya Panchayat Parishad was shortly due to be held and got a false case instituted against the petitioner at P. S. Tundi.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested at Dhanbad on 6th March, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was arrested at Dhanbad on 6th March, 1974 and after being produced before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, he was taken to Bhagalpur Central Jail

facts.text: Petitioner produced before Sub-Divisional Magistrate and taken to Bhagalpur Central Jail.

anchor.surface_text: and after being produced before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, he was taken to Bhagalpur Central Jail from Dhanbad.

facts.text: On March 11, 1974 petitioner applied to Sub-Divisional Magistrate for bail; no immediate order passed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1 1, 1974 the petitioner made an application to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate for being released on bail but numberimmediate order was passed on that application

facts.text: On 14th March, 1974 petitioner moved Sessions Judge for bail; bail granted.

anchor.surface_text: and the petitioner was, therefore, companystrained to move the Sessions Judge for bail on 14th March, 1974. The Sessions Judge granted bail to the petitioner

facts.text: On 18th March, 1974 Sub-Divisional Magistrate passed order for release of petitioner on bail bonds verified.

anchor.surface_text: and on the bail bonds being verified and accepted by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, an order dated 18th March, 1974 was passed for release of the petitioner.

facts.text: On 18th March, 1974 District Magistrate Dhanbad passed detention order under s3 MISA to prevent acts prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, that is 18th March, 1974, the District Magistrate, Dbanbad passed an order detaining the petitioner under section 3 of the Act on the ground that it was necessary

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 21st March, 1974 pursuant to detention order as soon as released on bail.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the order of detention, the petitioner was arrested on 21st March, 1974 as soon as he was released on bail in companypliance with the order of release

facts.text: Hindi and English versions of detention order and grounds served on petitioner; no material difference.

anchor.surface_text: passed by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate and at the time of his arrest the Hindi as well as English versions of the order of detention were served on him together with the grounds

facts.text: Ground 1: Petitioner propagating communal hatred between Adibasis and outsiders Biharis and between Adibasis and non-Adibasis for some time.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindi version, as translated in English, set out the following grounds of detention He has been propagating companymunal hatred between Adibasis and outsiders  Biharis  and also between Adibasis

facts.text: Incident on 25-2-1973 at Katras Ceramic Factory: petitioner instigated employees to remove outsiders Biharis by force; violence ensued.

anchor.surface_text: On 25-2-1973, at Katras Ceramic Factory, Tilatanr, P. S. Katras, District Dhanbad, he instigated the employees of the said ceramic factory to remove the outsiders  Biharis  by force

facts.text: Incident on 29-8-73 at Railway Football Maidan, Gomoh: petitioner speech instigating to take law in own hands.

anchor.surface_text: On 29-8-73, in the Railway Football Maidan, Gomob,P. S. Topchanchi, District Dhanbad, in companyrse of public speech, he asked the people to take law in their own hands

facts.text: Incident on 3-11-73: instigated adivasis and harijans to capture lands of non-Adibasis.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, on 3-11-73, at the said place, he, in a public meeting orga nised by Chotanagpur-Santbal Pargana Alag Raj Nirman Samity, instigated to local advasis

facts.text: Incident on 4-2-74 at Golf Ground Dhanbad: instigated to take law in hands.

anchor.surface_text: Again on 4-2-74, in Golf Ground, Dhanbad, P.S. and district Dhunbad, in a meeting of Adibasis organised by Jharkhand Party, be instigated the people to take the law

facts.text: Incident on 1-11-73 at Maachkocha and Mahatotund: instigation led to forcible taking of paddy crops.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-1 1-73, at village Maachkocha and Mahatotund,P. S. Topabanchi, District Dhanbad, in companysequence of instigation given by him and his companyassociates

facts.text: Incident on 3-3-74 at Singhdih: instigated to capture lands; procession damaged car.

anchor.surface_text: On 3-3-74, at village Singhdih, P.S. Topchanchi, district Dhanbad, he instigated the local Adivasis and Harijans in a Public meeting companyvened by Jharkhand

facts.text: Incident on 4-3-74 at Dumanda: organised meeting, instigated loot; on 5-3-74 unlawful assembly looted and set fire.

anchor.surface_text: On 4-3-74, at village Dumanda, P.S. Tundi, District Dhanbad, he organised a meeting of the Manjhis  Adibasis  and instigated them to loot the properties of Dikus

facts.text: Petitioner's representation to State Government rejected on 24th April, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: but this representation was rejected by the State Government on 24th April, 1974.

facts.text: Advisory Board opinion on 2nd May, 1974 that sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: gave its opinion on 2nd May, 1974 that there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on 11th May, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government thereafter companyfirmed the order of detention on 11th May, 1974.

facts.text: High Court petition under Art 226 rejected by Division Bench on 14th May, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: This detention order was challenged by the petitioner by filling a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Judicature at Patna. But a Division Bench

facts.text: Court held no infirmity in detention order; Hindi version authentic, English version error disregarded.

anchor.surface_text: But we do number find that there is any such infirmity in the order of detention. Whether we look at the Hindi version or the English version, the satisfaction which is recited

facts.text: Court rejected petitioner's contention that ground 1 vague.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then companytended that the first ground insofar as it alleged that the petitioner was propagating companymunal hatred, between Adivasis and other  Biharis

facts.text: Court held only instances in grounds 2-6 relied upon by DM.

anchor.surface_text: This ground is also, in our opinion, unsustainable. It is true that the District Magistrate stated in ground  1  that it would number be possible to give details

facts.text: Petition fails; rule discharged.

anchor.surface_text: These were the only grounds urged in support of the petition and since there is numbersubstance in them, the petition fails and the rule is discharged.

issues.text: Whether the English version of the grounds of detention reciting satisfaction that activities were prejudicial to the maintenance of public order or security of the State vitiates the order of detention due to disjunctive grounds?

anchor.surface_text: The first ground on which the validity of his detention was challenged on behalf of the petitioner was that the English version of the grounds of detention recited that the District Magistrate was satisfied that if the petitioner was allowed to remain at large he would indulge in activities prejudicial to the maintenance of public order or security of the State.

issues.text: Whether the first ground alleging propagation of communal hatred between Adibasis and outsiders/Biharis and between Adibasis and non-Adibasis is vague and unintelligible?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then contended that the first ground insofar as it alleged that the petitioner was propagating communal hatred, between Adivasis and other  Biharis  and also between Adivasis and non-Adivasis was vague and unintelligible and the order of detention was on that account invalid.

issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate took into account undisclosed instances beyond those in grounds 2 to 6 for subjective satisfaction?

anchor.surface_text: The next ground urged on behalf of the petitioner was that the District Magistrate had taken into account many more instances than those set out in grounds  2  to  6  and that was apparent from the use of the expression It would not be possible to give details of such instances in ground  1 .

issues.text: Whether the instance in ground 2 supports propagation of communal hatred between Adibasis and outsiders?

anchor.surface_text: It was then contended on behalf of the petitioner that the instance set out in ground  2  could not be regarded as one where communal hatred was propagated by the petitioner either between Adivasis and outsiders or between Adivasis and non-Adivasis and it did not, therefore, justify the inference set out in ground  1 .

issues.text: Whether the instance in ground 4 has nexus to maintenance of public order?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also contended that the instance set out in ground  4  was an instance involving removal of paddy crops from two plots of land in villages Marchacocha and Mahatotund and that could have no relation to maintenance of public order.

issues.text: Whether paragraphs 5 and 7 of the counter-affidavit indicate consideration of undisclosed materials by the District Magistrate?

anchor.surface_text: The last ground urged on behalf of the petitioner was that paragraphs 5 and 7 of the affidavit filed by Miss Sunila Dayal, Deputy Secretary to Government of Bihar, Home Department, in reply to the petition showed that there were various other materials in regard to the petitioner which were taken into account by the District Magistrate

arguments.claim: English version of grounds recites satisfaction for activities prejudicial to public order or security of State (disjunctive), showing District Magistrate did not apply mind seriously to whether acts fell under public order or security of State, vitiating detention order

court_response_anchor.surface_text: erated the satisfaction of the District Magistrate based on the same ground, namely, that the petitioner, if allowed to remain at large, would indulge

arguments.court_reasoning: Viewed in context of series of instances (grounds 2,3,5,6), part of acts affecting public order, not mere law and order

arguments.claim: Paragraphs 5 and 7 of counter-affidavit by Miss Sunila Dayal show District Magistrate considered various other undisclosed materials for subjective satisfaction without opportunity for representation

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s taken into account by the District Magistrate for the purpose of arriving at his subjective satisfaction in regard to the necessity of the detention

arguments.court_reasoning: Statements repel petitioner's allegation of being social worker; not facts considered by DM for satisfaction (DM affidavit confirms only listed grounds)

holdings.text: There is no infirmity in the order of detention arising from the English version reciting satisfaction for activities prejudicial to public order or security of the State, as the Hindi version (authentic) specifies only public order and the English addition is an inadvertent error.

anchor.surface_text: But we do number find that there is any such infirmity in the order of detention. Whether we look at the Hindi version or the English version, the satisfaction which is recited

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hindi is official language and authentic; English words 'or security of the State' incongruous with grounds specifying public order only; error inadvertent, cannot invalidate when totality shows public order basis.

holdings.text: The first ground alleging propagation of communal hatred between Adivasis and outsiders/Biharis and between Adivasis and non-Adivasis is not vague or unintelligible.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then companytended that the first ground insofar as it alleged that the petitioner was propagating companymunal hatred, between Adivasis and other  Biharis

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegation distinguishes groups clearly (Adivasis vs outsiders/Biharis, Adivasis vs non-Adivasis); supported by five detailed instances enabling effective representation.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate relied only on instances in grounds 2 to 6 for subjective satisfaction and did not consider undisclosed instances.

anchor.surface_text: The next ground urged on behalf of the petitioner was that the District Magistrate had taken into account many more instances than those set out in grounds  2  to  6

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'would not be possible to give details' means too many instances to list all, but only illustrative ones in grounds 2-6 relied upon; no undisclosed materials used.

holdings.text: The instance in ground 2 supports propagation of communal hatred between Adivasis and outsiders/Biharis and has direct nexus to maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: It was then companytended on behalf of the petitioner that the instance set out in ground  2  companyld number be regarded as one where companymunal hatred

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instigation to remove outsiders/Biharis by force led to violence by 200 armed persons; clearly communal hatred propagation with public order impact.

holdings.text: The instance in ground 4 has relation to maintenance of public order when viewed in context of series of instances.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also companytended that the instance set out in ground  4  was an instance involving removal of paddy crops from two plots of land

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not isolated law and order incident but part of pattern in grounds 2,3,5,6 affecting public order.

holdings.text: Paragraphs 5 and 7 of counter-affidavit do not indicate consideration of undisclosed materials by District Magistrate for subjective satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: The last ground urged on behalf of the petitioner was that paragraphs 5 and 7 of the affidavit filed by Miss Sunila Dayal, Deputy Secretary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statements repel petitioner's social worker claim; not facts used by DM (DM's affidavit confirms reliance only on listed grounds).

holdings.text: The petition fails as there is no substance in any of the grounds urged, and the rule is discharged.

anchor.surface_text: These were the only grounds urged in support of the petition and since there is numbersubstance in them, the petition fails and the rule is discharged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges rejected; detention order valid under MISA s.3.

precedents.citation: Kishori Mohan Bera v. The State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Kishori Mohan Bera v. The State of West Bengal 1

precedents.case_name: Kishori Mohan Bera v. The State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: if the order of detention purports to be based on the satisfaction of the detaining authority that it is necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order or security of the State, it would clearly be an invalid order because the satisfaction would be on disjunctive rather than conjunctive grounds, indicating lack of application of mind
